Plasfora Speech

good morning everyone
Let me take you on a quick journey…

Imagine a patient planning to travel for medical care — but instead of calling hospitals or agencies, he simply open an app, book an appointment, choose a country, and the rest is handled automatically.

This is the vision behind Plasfora — a SaaS platform built to support online medical tourism, making healthcare simple and accessible.I’m really proud that I joined the Plasfora adventure by developing the medical center management feature.

Today, I’m honored to present my end-of-studies project entitled ‘Development of a SaaS Application in Microservices for Medical Center Management’, carried out under the academic supervision of Dr. Salah Gontara and the professional supervision of Mr.Ahmed Mrabet

In front of my jury, colleagues, and family, I’m proud to share how this work supports a bigger dream: connecting patients and clinics through one platform.

To guide you through this journey,

my presentation will follow this structure:

General Context

Problematic & Solution

Project Specifications & Requirements

Microservices Development – Releases 1 & 2

CI/CD Pipeline – Release 3

Conclusion & Perspectives

General Context:

Let’s begin with the general context behind Plasfora.

which is divided into two main sections:

First, a brief presentation of the company, and second, the context of the project within the company."

Company Presentation:

"Plasfora is a Tunisian startup founded in 2021, specializing in AI-driven healthcare solutions .

With expertise in innovative medical solutions, custom software development, and advanced technology integration.

Project Context:

"our project follows 4 major steps :

Ideation & Research,

Define the Approach & Conception

Microservices Architecture Development,

Finally, CI/CD & Monitoring

Problematic & Solution:

Now, let's explore the problematic behind this project and our proposed solution.

Current Solution:

"Before diving into our solution, let's look at the existing system that Plasfora was using for medical center management.

As you can see from these screenshots, while functional, this current solution presented several challenges that limited its effectiveness and growth potential."

Problematic:

"The analysis of the current system revealed five critical issues:

Tight Coupling

Difficult Continuous Delivery

Limited Scalability -

Complex Maintenance

Reduced Team Productivity

These challenges made it clear that a fundamental architectural shift is necessary .

Proposed Solution:

As a team , we proposed a solution built on three core pillars:

Microservices Architecture - Breaking down the old monolithic system into mini applications which are our services

Scalability and Flexibility - Each service can scale based on demand

Improved CI/CD & Fault Isolation - Independent deployment pipelines for each service, with failures contained to specific components rather than affecting the entire system.

Competitive Analysis:

"To validate our approach, we analyzed key competitors in the medical tourism domain

This analysis confirmed that our approach would give Plasfora a competitive advantage.

 

Project specifications & Requirements :

System's Actors:

"Our system is designed around six key actors who interact with the platform:

Admin, Patient, Clinic, PDoctor, RefDoctor, and Commercial Agent.

Functional Requirements:

Instead of listing every action of users i will describe the core functional scenario :

The process begins when a Patient creates an account, logs in, and schedules an appointment with their desired date, location, and uploads their medical file.

This triggers an email notification to the Admin about the new appointment request.

Meanwhile, PDoctor and Clinic actors can add their availability - specifying dates and hours when they're operational.

The uploaded medical files are securely stored in an S3 bucket. The RefDoctor can review these files - but only if it matches their specialty - through a presigned URL that expires after one hour, ensuring security compliance. They then approve the case based on medical assessment.

Once approved, the Admin can see which clinics and doctors are available for the requested time slot and assigns the appropriate clinic and doctor to the appointment.

When everything is confirmed and the appointment is approved, all designated actors receive email notifications .

The Commercial Agent presents an optionnal actor that gives his code before appointment scheduling, allowing them to track their commission.

Non-Functional Requirements:

"Our system addresses six key non-functional requirements:

Scalability and Performance - handling growing loads with fast response times through microservices architecture.

Security - protecting medical data with S3 storage and presigned URLs for secure file access , JWT auth , RBAC

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Reliability and Availability - ensuring 24/7 uptime with fault-tolerant services.

Maintainability - modular architecture enabling easy updates.

Techs and tools used

Here’s a quick look at the main technologies and tools we used — including our backend frameworks, databases, message brokers, and DevOps tools that supported our development and deployment pipeline.

Microservices development ( release 1 &2 )

Sprint 0 :

Global Use Case Diagram
"We started by identifying the main actors and their interactions with the system. This diagram gave us a clear view of what each user can do within the application."

Class Diagram
"Next, we structured the core data model, focusing on key entities and their relationships — especially around the User class and its different roles."

General Architecture

"Finally, we set up the overall technical architecture, based on microservices, centralized routing via an API Gateway, and asynchronous communication using RabbitMQ between gateway and microservices and between microservices themselves ."

"In Sprint 1, we focused on building the core microservices that form the backbone of our system. We developed the Authentication service, the API Gateway for secure communication, as well as the Appointment and MedicalFolder services."

"Let’s take a quick look at how some of these features were implemented."

Sprint 1 :

Register / Login (Auth Microservice)
"Here’s a preview of the user registration and login flow — handled securely by the Authentication microservice."

Schedule Appointment (Appointment Microservice)
"This shows the scheduling process in action — managed by the Appointment microservice through the API Gateway."

Upload File / Approve Folder (MedicalFolder Microservice)
"And here, we see the file upload and approval workflow — a key part of the MedicalFolder service that supports appointment validation."

Sprint 2 :

"In Sprint 2, we continued expanding the system by implementing two key communication services: the Chat microservice and the Notification microservice."

"Let’s take a quick look at how they work in practice."

Chat Realization
"This is the real-time chat test — it allows users like patients and admin to communicate securely through the Chat microservice."

Notification Realization
"And here’s the notification system in action — showing how users receive emails for appointments, approvals, and other important events."

Sprint 3 :

"In Sprint 3, we added two new placeholder microservices: Hair and Dental."

"These are designed to handle specific types of medical files — for instance, if a user uploads a file tagged as 'hair' or 'dental', the system automatically routes it to the corresponding service and stores it in a dedicated bucket."

"Here’s a quick look at how this works."

Sequence Diagram (Hair example)
"This sequence diagram shows how an uploaded hair-related file is processed — from the client request to storage in the dedicated bucket via the Hair microservice."

File Registration Realization (Bucket)
"And here, you can see how the system creates and assigns a file to its specific storage bucket, based on the selected category like hair or dental."

CI / CD ( release 3 )
"After building the core microservices in previous sprints, we now move to Release 3 , where we focus on automation. This brings us to our CI/CD pipeline , a key part of scaling and maintaining our system efficiently."

CI/CD Application Overview
"Here’s a quick overview of our CI/CD pipeline — from code commit to deployment."

"It follows two main phases: Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Delivery (CD) ."

Key Features explication :

Flow :

"This automated flow allows fast, secure, and reliable deployments across all our microservices."

Sprint 4 :

"In Sprint 4, we focused exclusively on setting up the Continuous Integration (CI) phase of our CI/CD pipeline. This involved creating Dockerfiles for all microservices and the API Gateway, configuring an Azure VM for Jenkins, integrating Trivy for security scanning, and automating the build and push process to Docker Hub."

Key Features Covered in Sprint 4:

Sprint 5 :
"In Sprint 5, we moved from Continuous Integration to Continuous Delivery (CD) . Our goal was to automate the deployment of our microservices to production-like environments."

✅ We focused on three main tasks:

Let’s take a quick look at each part.

Helm Charts Code Snippet
"Here’s an example of one of our Helm charts — this is how we define and package each microservice for consistent and scalable deployments."

Install Argo CD on Kubernetes Cluster
"This shows the installation and setup of Argo CD , our GitOps tool for automated, declarative deployments on Kubernetes."

Deploy App on AKS
"And here, we see the final result — the full application successfully deployed and running on Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) ."

🧩 In resume :

"With Helm for packaging, Argo CD for automation, and AKS for orchestration, we now have a complete CD pipeline that enables fast, reliable, and version-controlled deployments."

Sprint 6 :
"In Sprint 6, we focused on two critical aspects: system monitoring and security ."

We:

Let’s take a quick look at the key results.

Cluster Visualization via Prometheus/Grafana
"This is our Kubernetes cluster monitoring dashboard — built using Prometheus for collecting metrics and Grafana for visualization. It gives us full visibility into system performance and health."

Domain with HTTPS & Cert Manager Snippet
"And here, you can see that our application is now securely accessible over HTTPS. This was achieved by automating SSL certificate issuance using Cert Manager and Let’s Encrypt ."

🧩 In resume :

"With real-time monitoring in place and HTTPS fully configured, Sprint 6 ensured that our system is not only performant but also secure and production-ready."

Conclusion and perspectives

"Now, let’s finish with a quick look at what we’ve built, what we’ve achieved, and where we’re going next."

Conclusion :

Plasfora is a scalable, cloud-native platform built with microservices for flexibility and easy maintenance. The API Gateway ensures smooth communication, while our automated DevOps pipeline enables fast and reliable updates. With efficient deployments and a flexible architecture, Plasfora is designed to grow and adapt — making it a solid foundation for the future. 
and the picture describe literraly what i talked about

Perspectives :

"Looking ahead, we’ll continue improving AI diagnostics, accuracy, and compliance — while scaling the platform for more users."

"We’ll also enhance our scalable architecture to support more users and features."

"We’re also adding tourism-related features , like travel health advisories and vaccination tracking, to support patients on the move."

Closing Thought :
"Plasfora is not just a healthcare platform — it’s a step toward smarter, safer, and more connected health experiences — wherever you are in the world."
